Portal 2 was a great successor to Portal. It has even harder puzzles and a deeper story. This is a great game to play while your friends are yelling at you.

Revisiting Portal 2 was a curious endeavor for me. I‚Äôd played it several times before, but never with the context of having played the first game. I had my reservations, already understanding that the sequel employs some‚Ä¶louder, stylistic choices.  Would Portal 2 be the same uproariously funny, exciting adventure buoyed by creative and stimulating puzzles?
	When the story begins, it becomes almost immediately apparent that something went wrong in Aperture. After a brief narrated stint, you wake to your resting space in disarray, only for the scene to come crashing around you soon after. Then you enter familiar test chambers from the first game, only now they‚Äôre wrought with disorder. The familiar chambers are dirtier, with uneven surfaces, making for a great contrast to the clean and pristine state which characterized these very same chambers for players of the first game. Furthermore, it feels like something is missing. It‚Äôs GLaDOS, of course; you start Portal 2 without her, and it makes her return all the more powerful. This brief absence is used to great effect, especially as a way to establish the state of Aperture Labs in the time since her defeat. There‚Äôs a peculiar loneliness and aimlessness captured at those points where you‚Äôre left to traipse Aperture without anyone directly addressing you. At times, the only voice accompanying your progress is pre-recorded, making for a curious atmosphere that aptly highlights the emptiness of Aperture.
	Eventually, you‚Äôll find yourself in new corners of the vast Aperture, and get a deeper look into its history. I find this to be the highlight of the story, as you get to see how Aperture‚Äôs frustrating past, and the ethics and business sense within. Portal 2‚Äôs structure is much akin to the first game‚Äôs, just stretched out and recontextualized. That‚Äôs not too say Portal 2 is drawn out, and in fact I feel it may have benefitted from just a few more hours spent at its best.
	You‚Äôll meet some new faces along the way, key among them Wheatley, a quirky and not-all-too-brilliant core whose banter accompanies you for much of the adventure. Wheatley is, on the whole, a fun addition, with his rash decision-making contrasting GLaDOS‚Äô precise nature. Unfortunately, Whealtey can get grating, perhaps epitomizing more than anything else Portal 2‚Äôs occasional divulgence into over-the-top slapstick which just doesn‚Äôt completely mesh with the tone of the rest of the game.
	On the whole, the story makes for a satisfying continuation of Portal‚Äôs foundation. See, Portal was so self-contained and complete that adding on was a risky venture, but I feel the writers found a good solution, though I understand some may feel this game dives too deep into the background of Aperture and GLaDOS, leaving too little to the imagination. Obscurity was a strength of the first Portal, and Portal 2 does do away with some of that mystique, and your mileage may vary with the reveals. I think they‚Äôre mostly strong, although certain character turns can feel rushed or undercooked.
	The shift to a more cinematic approach does mean Portal 2‚Äôs story loses quite a bit of the first game‚Äôs subtlety. Its jokes are also more direct and frequent, but I don‚Äôt think they land as consistently. Perhaps it‚Äôs because I initially played this game on Xbox 360, but I also feel the more cinematic style feels comparably more ‚Äúat home‚Äù on a TV.
	As far as gameplay goes, Portal 2 manages to expand on the original‚Äôs foundation admirably. It‚Äôs not much of a refinement per se, but only because Portal left little to touch up ‚Äì such was its tight and focused design ‚Äì but there are still some subtle quality-of-life changes. As an example, the game now makes a greater effort to course-correct certain scenarios. When you jump to fall into a portal on the floor, the game will line you up to fall directly in if you‚Äôre close enough. Similarly, creating a fall loop is no longer subject to slight tweaks in your placement with every loop, so you‚Äôll never find yourself falling out of the loop unintentionally.
	You‚Äôll spend less time on single-portal puzzles at the start of the game. These still may feel trite to experienced Portal players, but the puzzles are tightened up to ensure you can move quickly through them. I do feel you perhaps spend a bit too much time in the familiar puzzle chamber space, whereas I feel Portal 2 has an immediately stronger sense of identity and confidence when you leave that space, following a pivotal turning point in the story. I feel the experience would have been better served allocating more time to that portion of the game while trimming the more traditional Aperture chambers in the game‚Äôs earlier chapters.
	New mechanics abound, even if it takes some time for them to appear. The gels are stellar additions, and really serve to show how each new mechanic allows new interplay with existing ones. Co-op chambers are well-considered too, really exploring a wealth of puzzle ideas not possible with only one player and one portal gun. The final boss is a smashing improvement over the first game, with creative use of various mechanics and a thrillingly surprising conclusion.
	Scripted action sequences are much more frequent here. They‚Äôre usually fairly basic to navigate; any time a real puzzle shows itself, you‚Äôre likely under no pressure to finish it in a certain amount of time. This can make them feel a bit toothless on repeat playthroughs, as the urgency isn‚Äôt there.
	Co-op allows the game to really stretch its mechanics even further. These aren‚Äôt just single player puzzles with a companion, but fully realized solutions requiring an extra set of hands (and portals). Solving the chambers is more involved, but more satisfying in turn. However, it can be a bit deflating when your partner devises the answer all by themselves. The humor is on-point here, but the story is downplayed. The story itself is disappointingly straightforward, and veers into complete slapstick in the end scenes; it feels like the game has lost almost all narrative edge in favor of pure comedy. I always looked forward to the final puzzle of a set in co-op, as they place you outside the regular chamber space for an even more involved puzzle. The final set of chambers is the stronger of the bunch, a true culmination for the campaign. The DLC is also rather fun and challenging. Clever pinging tools enable stronger communication with your partner. Co-op definitely isn‚Äôt just slapped on to capitalize on the multiplayer trend of the time. I do wish the campaign had a more substantive story, even if I understand the risks of a story-heavy multiplayer experience. Nonetheless, the actual puzzle-solving is stellar stuff.
	The environmental design is once again brilliant, with the deterioration and system failures highlighting the decay of the facility. You get to see the lab break down and rebuild itself before your very eyes, and it‚Äôs a sight to see. After GLaDOS awakens, the chambers start to clean themselves up, and the cameras begin to watch you again.  Contrast is effectively utilized here, as you‚Äôll see Aperture through the years and under the guiding hand of very different personalities.
	The strong presentation enables several sequences ‚Äì including the punchy opening ‚Äì which convey the scale of Aperture and its ruination. Physics are put to great effect when sizable structures crash into one another. It‚Äôs a great spectacle. There are also plenty of opportunities to gaze upon Aperture‚Äôs immensity, with structures stretching in vast space, as far as the field-of-view will permit. The only downside to the visuals is that, as with some other Valve-developed Source games, the lighting setup can drown darker areas in pitch black without manually applying a tone mapping occlusion fix in the video configuration files.
	The soundtrack is strong, with numerous electronic pieces which set the mood nicely. Different puzzle and interactive elements have their own musical cues when in effect, conveying
Amazing game, engulfing and charming storyline, and amazingly designed puzzles! If only they made a Portal 3...

Ok this game is amazing, lets start with the game play, this is a puzzle game that makes you think and I love that and there are a ton of levels not just in the run down aperature in the beginning.

Also the story is great, You start by meeting the core wheatley, a british sentient AI, You also meet GladOS Who has been upset with you ever since you killed her, along with more fun stuff

Finnaly the game is comedy, take it or leave it, even with the slightly dark plot.

One of the best games ever. It's worthy of the hype (even all these years later). 
Also, once you have finished the game, there is an endless number of player created levels and mods which are legit and through the Steam Workshop. They are so easy to use it's almost like they are official maps. Some are practically impossible. It will make your brain hurt! But the satisfaction you get from figuring a puzzle out is huge. The story is fascinating. 
Remind yourself that you are really smart! Play Portal 1 first, imho but you dont have to. Portal 1 I was part of the Orange Box bundle years ago. It was just a little side game but it became one of the best biggest games of all time. I just love it so much.
I have 6.9 hours on this game. Nice

This game has an incredible, deep story and great portal mechanics, not to mention one of the best single-player campaigns I've ever played through, having played through it many times. Highly recommend.
